@XiaoZYang, In CI "Maven clean install", there was a log said:
```
[INFO] Running org.apache.pulsar.broker.service.PersistentTopicTest
Build timed out (after 100 minutes). Marking the build as aborted.
```
Would you please verify the test "PersistentTopicTest" locally? Not sure if this is a wrong report, since Integration tests passed.
@piotrblasiak I was actually thinking we could remove the maven/gradle snippets completely. If you click on the artifact maven central will give you the snippet.

I was told to use pulsar-client-admin instead but that in turn gave me a deps problem:

`java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: com.fasterxml.jackson.jaxrs.cfg.EndpointConfigBase.<init>(Lcom/fasterxml/jackson/databind/cfg/MapperConfig;)V`

It seems that the whole pulsar project depends on jersey-media-json-jackson 2.9, which in turn depends on jackson-jaxrs-base 2.3.2 while the jackson version used in the pulsar project is actually much higher (2.9.3). Is this a bug or is it just because I use the pulsar-client-admin artifact?

A workaround is to do this:

```
<dependency>
			<groupId>org.apache.pulsar</groupId>
			<artifactId>pulsar-client-admin-original</artifactId> <!-- https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/issues/1409 -->
			<version>${pulsar.version}</version>
			<exclusions>
				<!-- https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/issues/1409 -->
				<exclusion>
					<groupId>com.fasterxml.jackson.jaxrs</groupId>
					<artifactId>jackson-jaxrs-json-provider</artifactId>
				</exclusion>
			</exclusions>
		</dependency>
		<!-- https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/issues/1409 -->
		<dependency>
			<groupId>com.fasterxml.jackson.jaxrs</groupId>
			<artifactId>jackson-jaxrs-json-provider</artifactId>
			<version>${jackson.version}</version>
		</dependency>
```

Seems the error happens in `NamespaceService.splitAndOwnBundle()`. 
The concurrent update of Policies will cause some override to bundles value that kept in Zookeeper. And this involves at least 2 rounds of split. 
e.g.
1. At beginning, we have 2 bundles, with partitions:[0x00000000, 0x7fffffff, 0xffffffff],

2. First round of split: We will split the 2 bundles at the same time.
  for first bundle split, the `NamespaceBundles` value that returned by `NamespaceBundleFactory.splitBundles()` would be: 
[0x00000000, *0x3fffffff*, 0x7fffffff, 0xffffffff]; 
while at the same time, the `NamespaceBundles` value for second bundle split would be:
 [0x00000000, 0x7fffffff, *0xbfffffff*, 0xffffffff]

3. Then the 2 split operations, whoever success `updateNamespaceBundles` last, will override the former one. 
Here if second split finally success,  it will override the former success value [0x00000000, *0x3fffffff*, 0x7fffffff, 0xffffffff], and the final bundles partitions would be:  [0x00000000, 0x7fffffff, *0xbfffffff*, 0xffffffff];  But we thought it should be [0x00000000, *0x3fffffff*, 0x7fffffff, *0xbfffffff*,  0xffffffff]; 

4. Second round split:  e.g. try to split to range [0x00000000, 0x3fffffff], it will not find upper boundary 0x3fffffff in actual [0x00000000, 0x7fffffff, 0xbfffffff, 0xffffffff].
And  this will cause the error:â€¨

```â€¨
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Invalid upper boundary for bundle
    at com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkArgument(Preconditions.java:122)
â€¨```

Thanks @zhaijack for looking into. Do you think this could be solved validating the z-node version? We could have a loop of read-modify-write retrying when there are simultaneous write to the z-node, and refreshing with the latest version of the split list.
@lucperkins @merlimat what do you think of removing the maven/gradle examples completely, since they're already in maven central?
Thanks @merlimat for the suggestion, It seems work-able, will try on this way
@maskit @merlimat - have addressed all your concerns and added additional test cases. Kindly review it again and give me a +1

> Currently if the producer and consumer has a difference in timestamp (average t) then we can just add t and still get E2E latency 

If the clocks are skewed, I don't think there's a reliable way to get the e2e latency
...actually that was the reason why I didn't put the e2e latency initially.

> ...actually that was the reason why I didn't put the e2e latency initially.

Exactly, cause in different machine scenario this value will never be accurate (or even in same machine using NTP). So I would recommend leaving the code as it is and just add a disclaimer explaining why E2E latency can't be reliable.

> . So I would recommend leaving the code as it is and just add a disclaimer explaining why E2E latency can't be reliable. 

As it is, it gives exception..
@rdhabalia I think there was a problem with shading and dependencies to solve for this
yeah, I saw that cyclic dependency issue while bringing everything under `PulsarAdmin`. Will reopen if I will be able to fix it in a cleaner way.
@rdhabalia Please take a look as well
@rdhabalia I'm seeing this multiple times. Would it make sense to increase the timeout from 6seconds to something like 30?

@ivankelly I'd leave the maven snippet (Don't care much about gradle since I don't use it :) ), since it's visually easy to figure out. Though, I'd prefer the version directly in the `<dependency>` tags instead of the variable indirection, just to make it easier to copy/paste.
